entry.title: X509 certificate - Fields & extensions
entry.summary:
For X509 certificate, the fields and extension are defined by the RFC5280. As well, the CA/B Forum (Certificate Authority & Browser Forum) defines best pratice. This post is a memo to remind the main fields and extension.

Basic certificate field

Field Description
Subject The subject must be populated with a non-empty distinguished name. The DN must be defined, at least: Common Name, Organization Name and Organization Unit
Serial Number This is certificate identifier. So it must be unique for each certificate issued by a given CA. According to best practice, the first serial number must be defined randomly. Then, the number must be increased randomly.

Certificate extension

Extension Description
Subject Key Identifier This identifier is a way to identify the public key. This identifier should be derived from the public key (for example: with SHA-1)
Authority Key Identifier This extension must be equal to the "Subject Key Identifier" of the Certification Authority
Key Usage This extension defines the purpose of the key contained in the certificate
Extended Key Usage This extension defines the purpose of the key in addition to or in place of the basic purposes indicated in the key usage extension
Basic Constraints This extension identifies whether the subject of the certificate is a CA and the maximum depth of valid certification paths that include this certificate
Authority Information Access This extension indicates how to access information and services of the CA (on-line validation services and CA policy data). Example: "OCSP;URI:http://ocsp.example.com/RootCA/"
crlDistributionPoints This extension defines how to obtain CRL. Example: "URI:http://www.example.com/RootCA.crl"

Critical or Non critical: A software must reject the certificate if it encounters a critical extension that it doesn't recognize, or a critical extension that contains information that it can't process. A non-critical extension may be ignored if it is not recognized, but must be processed if it is recognized.

entry.title: How to migrate from OpenRC to SystemD
entry.summary:
SystemD is an initialization system for Linux created in 2010. Now, most of Linux distribution (Debian, Arch, ...) use SystemD instead of original initialization system (sysvinit, upstart, ...).

However, the default initialization system used by Gentoo Linux is OpenRC which is slower than SystemD. This article describes how to replace OpenRC by SystemD on Gentoo Linux.

Kernel configuration

| Gentoo Linux --->
|      |     Support for init systems, system and service managers --->
|      |      | [ ] OpenRC, runit and other script based systems and managers
|      |      | [*] systemd
|
| General setup  --->
|      | [*] Configure standard kernel features (expert users)  --->
|      |      | [*] Enable eventpoll support
|      |      | [*] Enable signalfd() system call
|      |      | [*] Enable timerfd() system call
|
| Processor type and features  --->
|      | (root=/dev/sda6 init=/usr/lib/systemd/systemd) Built-in kernel command string

Another options are mandatory or recommended but they are already enabled. More informations on wiki.gentoo.org/wiki/Systemd

Systemd installation

Select profil for systemd (default/linux/amd64/13.0/desktop/kde/systemd)

# eselect profile list
# eselect profile set 7

Update system

# emerge -DN @world

Systemd configuration

Define hostname

# nano /etc/hostname
lenovo

Define keyboard layout

# localectl list-keymaps
# localectl set-keymap fr-latin9

Define time zone

# timedatectl list-timezones
# timedatectl set-timezone Europe/Paris

Define NTP client

# nano /etc/systemd/timesyncd.conf

NTP=0.fr.pool.ntp.org 1.fr.pool.ntp.org 2.fr.pool.ntp.org 3.fr.pool.ntp.org

Start NTP client

# systemctl enable systemd-timesyncd
# systemctl start systemd-timesyncd
# timedatectl set-ntp true

Check NTP client

# timedatectl status

Enable services

KDM (KDE Display Manager)

# systemctl enable kdm.service

NetworkManager

# systemctl enable NetworkManager.service

NFS (Network File System)

# systemctl enable nfs-client.target

AutoFS

# systemctl enable autofs.service

libVirtd

# systemctl stop libvirtd

entry.title: Let’s Encrypt
entry.summary:
Let's Encrypt, is a Certificate Authority created by Linux Fundation in 2015, which issues certificate freely and automatically.

Let's Encrypt uses the ACME (Automated Certificate Management Environment) protocol to issue certificates without any human intervention. This is accomplished by running a certificate management agent on the web server.

An automated process avoids human errors such as forgetting certificate renewal or mishandling private key.

Thanks to an automated issuance, the certificate lifetime may be reduced to 90 days. This short lifetime limits damage from key compromise and mis-issuance. Stolen keys and mis-issued certificates are valid for a shorter period of time.

Let's Encrypt is a recent certificate authority and the root certificate authority is not yet trusted in most browsers. In order to be broadly trusted right away, the intermediate certificate is also cross-signed by another certificate authority, IdenTrust. This trick introduces a weakness because the root certificate of IdenTrust is signed with SHA1 algorithm.

entry.title: How to install Chromium with Flash support
entry.summary:
In 2012, Adobe has stopped to upgrade Flash Player for Linux. So, the last version of Flash Player plugin is 11.2 that will be maintained until 2017. To continue to take the advantage of Flash content, we must find an alternative solution.

This tutorial describes how to install Chromium and the Flash Pepper Plugin (PPAPI) on Gentoo Linux and how to configure Chromium for graphic hardware acceleration.

Chromium

Define local USE flags

# nano /etc/portage/package.use
>=media-libs/libvpx-1.4.0       postproc

Install Chromium

# emerge chromium

To configure Chromium, open chrome://flags :

  • Override software rendering list : enable
  • GPU rasterization : enable

To check if Chromium uses hardware acceleration, open chrome://gpu and look under "Graphics Feature status". All (or at least most of) the features should say "hardware accelerated".

Flash Player

To get Chrome and its plugins, download the RPM package for Linux 64bits on Google

entry.title: Extended Validation Certificate
entry.summary:
An Extended Validation Certificate is a digital certificate issue by a Certificate Authority in conformity with "Baseline Requirements" and "EV SSL Certificate Guidelines". These documents are defined by CA/B Forum (Certificate Authority & Browser Forum). This article is a summary of EV SSL Certificate Guidelines version 1.5.6 of 25 june 2015.

Additional content

For an Extended Validation Certificate, these subject attributes are required :

  • Subject Organization Name
  • Subject Alternative Name Extension
  • Subject Common Name
  • Subject Business Category
  • Subject Jurisdiction of Incorporation or Registration
  • Subject Registration Number
  • Subject Physical Address of Place of Business

Verification Requirements

The verification processes are intended to accomplish the following:

  • Verify Applicant’s existence and identity, including :
    • Verify the Applicant’s legal existence and identity,
    • Verify the Applicant’s physical existence (business presence at a physical address)
    • Verify the Applicant’s operational existence (business activity)
  • Verify the Applicant is a registered holder, or has control, of the Domain Name(s) to be included in the EV Certificate
  • Verify a reliable means of communication with the entity to be named as the Subject in the Certificate;
  • Verify the Applicant’s authorization for the EV Certificate, including :
    • Verify the name, title, and authority of the Contract Signer, Certificate Approver, and Certificate Requester,
    • Verify that a Contract Signer signed the Subscriber Agreement or that a duly authorized Applicant Representative acknowledged and agreed to the Terms of Use
    • Verify that a Certificate Approver has signed or otherwise approved the EV Certificate Request.

Audit

A Certificate Authority issuing EV certificates shall undergo an audit in accordance with one of the following schemes:

  • WebTrust Program for CAs audit and WebTrust EV Program audit
  • ETSI TS 102 042 : "Policy requirements for certification Authorities issuing public key certificates"

entry.title: CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)
entry.summary:
CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) is a mechanism, define by W3C, which provides a way for web servers to support cross-site access controls, which enable secure cross-site data transfers.

This mechanism works by adding new HTTP headers named Access-Control-Allow-Origin.

Step 1 : Create WebService

Create a PHP script named "cors.php" and hosted on "www.example.com" :

<?
  header("Access-Control-Allow-Origin: http://hostname:8000");
  echo date("Y-m-d H:i:s");
?>

Step 2 : Create HTML web page

Create a HTML file named "cors.html" and hosted on your computer :

<!doctype html>
<html>
 <body>

 <script>
  var xmlHttp = new XMLHttpRequest();
  xmlHttp.open( "GET", "http://www.example.com/cors.php", false );
  xmlHttp.send( null );
  alert(xmlHttp.responseText);
 </script>

 </body>
</html>

To test easily, start a web server with python (in the directory where the file "cors.html" is located)

python -m SimpleHTTPServer

Then, open web page from http://hostname:8000/cors.html

entry.title: JSONP (JSON with Padding)
entry.summary:
This article shows how JSONP (JavaScript Object Notation with Padding) can be used to get data from different domains, bypassing SOP (Same-Origin Policy).

JSONP uses the script tag, which is not in the scope of the SOP. Indeed, a JavaScript source file loaded from another domain will run in the origin of the HTML that includes the script, not in the domain where the JavaScript file originated from.

Step 1 : Create JSONP WebService

The web service encapsulates data, in JSON format, in a callback function. Create a PHP script named "jsonp.php" and hosted on "www.example.com" :

<?
 $MyData = '{ "MyDateTime": "' . date("Y-m-d H:i:s") . '" }';
 echo $_GET['JsonpCallback'] . '(' . $MyData . ');';
?>

Step 2 : Create HTML web page

The HTML page loads the JavaScript source file, from JSONP WebService, then execute the callback function. Create the HTML page named jsonp.html and hosted on your localhost :

<!doctype html>
<html>
 <head>

  <script type="text/javascript">

    function LoadJavaScript() {
      var script = document.createElement('script');
      script.src = 'http://www.example.com/jsonp.php?JsonpCallback=MyJsonpCallbackFunction';
      document.body.appendChild(script);
    }

    function MyJsonpCallbackFunction(DataArgument) {
      var MyJson = JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(DataArgument));
      alert(MyJson["MyDateTime"]);
    }

  </script>

 </head>
 <body>
   <button type="button" onclick="LoadJavaScript();">Click me to display Date and Time</button>
 </body>
</html>

JSONP limits

JSONP only supports Cross-Origin HTTP GET request. Even more, the server could be compromised and return arbitrary code that will be executing in the context of your page (thus allowing access to your site’s cookies, localStorage, ...)

  • Code Project, JSON to JSONP: Bypass Same-Origin Policy

entry.title: TLS: Understanding the cipher suites
entry.summary:
To protect your communications, TLS protocol uses 4 cryptographic functions: key exchange, authentication, encryption and message authentication code. Cipher suite allows to define the algorithm used for each of these 4 functions.

Cryptographic function

Key exchange

This cryptographic function is used to define a common secret (the master secret key) between two parties. Available algorithms are RSA, DH, DHE and ECDHE.

Authentication

This cryptographic function is used to authenticate the server by client and optionally the client by server. Available algorithms are RSA or DSS.

Encryption

This cryptographic function is used to encrypt data. Available algorithms are DES, 3DES, RC4, AES, ...

Message Authentication Code

This cryptographic function is used to sign data. Available algorithms are MD5, SHA, SHA256, ...

Cipher suites

Cipher suite is a list of one or more cipher strings separated by special char (colon, comma, space, ...). The names for cipher suites are defined by IANA (Internet Assigned Numbers Authority).

Cipher suite defines algorithms used for each cryptographic function: key exchange, authentication, encryption and message authentication code. If algorithm for key exchange is not mentioned, default algorithm is RSA.

The table below details some example of cipher suites:

entry.title: HowTo support FAT64 on Gentoo
entry.summary:
FAT64 or ExFAT (Extended File Allocation Table) is a file system introduced in 2009 by Microsoft. This is the successor to FAT32 that addresses the need to store larges files. With FAT64, the theoretical maximum file size is 64 ZB instead of 4GB for FAT32.

This file systen is supported by Microsoft Windows (XP, Vista, Seven,...), MacOS, Linux and Android. For linux, FAT64 is not supported directly in the kernel but with FUSE (Filesystem in UserSpacE).

This article describes step by step how to support FAT64 on Gentoo Linux.

Installation

Kernel configuration :

|     File systems  --->
|      | <*> FUSE (Filesystem in Userspace) support
|      | <*>   Character device in Userspace support

software installation :

# emerge sys-fs/fuse-exfat sys-fs/exfat-utils

Usage

Format the partition

# mkfs.exfat /dev/sdxy

Check the partition

# fsck.exfat /dev/sdxy

Mount the partition

# mount -t exfat /dev/sdxy /mnt/usb

References

  • Microsoft - Description of the ExFAT file system driver

entry.title: HowTo make a web site with Pelican hosted on GitHub Pages
entry.summary:
Pelican is a static site generator writed in Python. This means that you edit the content on your computer with a simple text editor. Then, a generator makes all HTML pages for the web site, including indexes for articles, categories and tags. In the end, your web site can be hosted easily on a simple HTTP server like GitHub Pages or Amazon S3.

Unlike other CMS (Content Management System) like Wordpress or Drupal, Pelican has no web administration interface. In most cases, the administration interface has many vulnerabilies used to deface the website.

This article describes step by step how to make your web site with Pelican 3.5 on Gentoo Linux and how to host your web site on GitHub Pages.

Install Pelican

# emerge pelican

Create GitHub space

On GitHub, create an account named "didier-bernaudeau" then a repository named "didier-bernaudeau.github.io". Obviously, remplace "didier-bernaudeau" by your username.

DNS Configuration

Add a record in the DNS :

Type : CNAME
Name : didier.bernaudeau.net
Value : didier-bernaudeau.github.io.

Check configuration with "dig" tool :

# emerge bind-tools

$ dig didier.bernaudeau.net +nostats +nocomments +nocmd

; <<>> DiG 9.10.1-P1 <<>> didier.bernaudeau.net +nostats +nocomments +nocmd
;; global options: +cmd
;didier.bernaudeau.net.         IN      A
didier.bernaudeau.net.  10800   IN      CNAME   didier-bernaudeau.github.io.
didier-bernaudeau.github.io. 3600 IN    CNAME   github.map.fastly.net.
github.map.fastly.net.  30      IN      A       185.31.17.133

Create local directory

$ git clone https://github.com/didier-bernaudeau/didier-bernaudeau.github.io.git/ MyWebSite
$ cd MyWebSite

Create project

$ pelican-quickstart

> Where do you want to create your new web site? [.]
> What will be the title of this web site? D. Bernaudeau
> Who will be the author of this web site? D. Bernaudeau
> What will be the default language of this web site? [en]
> Do you want to specify a URL prefix? e.g., http://example.com   (Y/n) Y
> What is your URL prefix? (see above example; no trailing slash) http://didier.bernaudeau.net
> Do you want to enable article pagination? (Y/n) n
> Do you want to generate a Fabfile/Makefile to automate generation and publishing? (Y/n) Y
> Do you want an auto-reload & simpleHTTP script to assist with theme and site development? (Y/n) n
> Do you want to upload your website using FTP? (y/N) N
> Do you want to upload your website using SSH? (y/N) N
> Do you want to upload your website using Dropbox? (y/N) N
> Do you want to upload your website using S3? (y/N) N
> Do you want to upload your website using Rackspace Cloud Files? (y/N) N
> Do you want to upload your website using GitHub Pages? (y/N) y
> Is this your personal page (username.github.io)? (y/N) y

Download the theme

For my web site, I selected the theme "Bootstrap3" and the style sheet "Bootswatch".

$ cd MyWebSite
$ git clone https://github.com/DandyDev/pelican-bootstrap3.git/ theme
$ cd theme/static/css/
$ wget https://bootswatch.com/bower_components/bootstrap/dist/css/bootstrap.min.css
$ wget https://bootswatch.com/bower_components/bootstrap/dist/css/bootstrap.css

Moreover, I have edited the theme to change the font size of "blockquote" section (bootstrap.flatly.min.css).

Download plugins

$ cd MyWebSite
$ git clone --recursive https://github.com/getpelican/pelican-plugins plugins

Install Bootstrapify

Bootstrapify is a pelican plugin that modify article and page html to use bootstrap's default classes, especially tables. Beautiful Soup is requiered for Bootstrapify.

# emerge dev-python/beautifulsoup

Create GitHub Files

$ cd MyWebSite
$ mkdir content/GitHubFiles

Write your domain name in CNAME Files :

$ nano content/GitHubFiles/CNAME

didier.bernaudeau.net

Disable indexation by web search engine :

$ nano content/GitHubFiles/robots.txt

User-agent: *
Disallow:/

Pelican Configuration

$ nano pelicanconf.py

# Hide Blogroll
#LINKS =

# Hide Social widget
#SOCIAL =

# Define the theme
THEME = 'theme/'
BOOTSTRAP_THEME = 'flatly'

# Define menu options
DISPLAY_CATEGORIES_ON_MENU = True
DISPLAY_PAGES_ON_MENU = True

# Define index options
DISPLAY_ARTICLE_INFO_ON_INDEX = True
SUMMARY_MAX_LENGTH = 50

# Add description about author
ABOUT_ME = '...'

# Define sidebar options (With cloud tag)
DISPLAY_TAGS_ON_SIDEBAR = True
DISPLAY_TAGS_INLINE = True

# Add Creative Common licence in the footer
CC_LICENSE = 'CC-BY-NC-ND'

# Add plugins (Summary)
PLUGIN_PATHS = ['plugins']
PLUGINS = ['summary','bootstrapify']

# Add static paths will be copied without parsing their contents
STATIC_PATHS = ['images','presentation', 'GitHubFiles']

# Shift the installed location of a file
EXTRA_PATH_METADATA = {
   'GitHubFiles/CNAME': {'path': 'CNAME'},
   'GitHubFiles/robots.txt': {'path': 'robots.txt'},
}

Create an article in reStructuredText

$ nano content/test.rst

Article title
#############

:date: AAAA-MM-JJ HH:MM
:modified: AAAA-MM-JJ HH:MM
:tags: word1, word2
:category: MyCategory
:slug: Article-title
:authors: MyName

Introduction ...

.. PELICAN_END_SUMMARY

Content ...

Generate the web site

$ make html

Preview the web site

$ make serve
$ firefox localhost:8000

Publish the web site on GitHub

$ make github

Username for 'https://github.com': didier-bernaudeau
Password for 'https://didier-bernaudeau@github.com': *************************

References

  • Pelican
  • Pelican plugins
  • Pelican theme - Bootstrap 3
  • How to set up a Pelican blog with Github pages (by Dheepak Krishnamurthy)
